title: How many notes does it usually take for a melody to be recognized? - Quora

response.answer_text: A melody consists of a sequence of pitches in a certain rhythm. A melody can either repeat the same note or move up or down by interval. It can take as little as two notes to recognize a melody, especially if a distinctive interval is used at the beginning of the melody. For example, an ascending minor seventh is used at the beginning of the song “Somewhere” from “West Side Story.” An ascending augmented fourth is used at the beginning of two songs (also both from “West Side Story”)—“Maria” and “Cool.” A descending major sixth would usually indicate the Willie Nelson country classic “Crazy.” A descending minor third could indicate “Hey Jude.” Those first two notes of “Hey Jude” are very distinctive, with or without the words. It seems to me that a strong melody should be recognized by the fourth or fifth note. Think “Georgia On My Mind,” “My Funny Valentine,” “I Could Have Danced All Night,” “Over the Rainbow,” “Amazing Grace,” “When the Saints Go Marching In” or “Yesterday.” The exception might be the case when a single note is repeated several times at the beginning of the song—such as in “Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da” or “One Note Samba.” In that event, it may take more notes to recognize the melody.
